page.title: 01Hawkhope and Bellingburn
page.content: {General overview} Much of the area covered by this grid rectangle is taken up by forest and water. Along the southern edge of the block is{Kielder Water,} with the northern end of the{Kielder Dam}just included. This part of the shoreline alternates between sandy inlets and rocky promontories. The{Belling Crag}once towered some 90 feet from its base to its summit. Now only the top 15 feet are exposed above the dark waters. The{Belling Burn}makes inroads into the forest which now covers the rest of the 12 square km. Wide forest rides are the only break in the tree cover. One of Northumberland's last remaining {drift mines} still operates in the forest, about 1km north west of the North Abuttment of the dam.
